div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: HISTORICAL MYTHS.
div.p: "Better the oppression of the Turks than the justice of the Arabs." Egyptian proverb.

This myth has not yet been, so to speak, added to the Nationalist repertoire, though it may yet be advertised in the "Egyptian Standard" pour embêter les Anglais--Conservateurs--and to encourage Messrs. Robertson and Rutherford. Thus far it has been principally exploited for the benefit of European Turcophobes by Negib Bey Azoury, the author of a work entitled "Le Reveil de la Nation Arabe," the title of which assumes as a premise that an Arab nation exists-a 'large order to anyone who has studied recent Oriental history with the slightest care. Negib Bey denounces the venality and tyranny of the Turkish rulers of Syria, describes the Osmanli language as a barbarous jargon which has given no word but the degrading term 'backsheesh' to the Arab vocabulary, and declares that the Osmanlis are, for the most part, irreclaimable barbarians. The Turk has evidently failed to satisfy Azoury Bey: let us see what the Arab has done in recent times to deserve the commendation of our author.

As far as we can discover he has done nothing but plot or rebel against the Turk: To an ardent anti-Turk this is no doubt most praiseworthy, but the sober student of history will not see anything very meritorious in plots that fail, and rebellions that now burn up, now die down, always smoulder, and never entirely overcome the sword or the diplomacy of the Sultan. At present the Arabs of the Yemen are in arms against the Padishah. They have inflicted some severe defeats upon bi armies and have enabled the Turkish War Office to give monumental proofs of its incapacity. But they have failed to co-operate with the Arab tribes of the Hedjaz or Nejd, and the religious fanaticism which leads their chiefs to proclaim that the Turks are base latitudinarians - hardly better than the "Kufâr" - can hardly recommend them to the sympathy of the civilised world. Of the Arabs of the present day the great majority are in the tribal stage and lead a precarious and nomadic life in more or less desolate regions. Even those who dwell in towns or cultivate fertile oases or terraced mountains where heavy rains fall, have made no political progress whatever since the days of the Abbasids. In fact they have, if anything, declined since those days. Under the earlier Abbasid Caliphs the Arab tribes and the settled folk of Arabia were usually the faithful subjects of the Arab rulers of Baghdad. To day all of Arabia which is outside the range of foreign artillery is at best lawless, at worst anarchical, and by the irony of fate an approach to security can alone be found in Arabia (Aden excepted) under the sway of the "unspeakable" Tork. But it may be urged that it is hardly fair to take the Arabs of to-day for the purposes of such a comparison, and that the Turks have never produced a civilisation such as distinguished the role of the Omeyyads of Cordova or Damascus, of the Abbasids of Baghdad, of the Fatimids of Cairo.

Now we will postpone for the moment the consideration of the questions, "How far were the Arabs or Islam responsible for this civilisaion? Was it the product of the Moslem. Din' or the Arab Muruwwa' l"and content ourselves with pointing out that the Osmanli Turks-

owing in part to their own manly virtues, their extraordinary sense of discipline, their courage and the continuity of their policy, in part to their conscious adoption of Byzantine methods of organisation and Government -- methods derived from the organisation and state craft of those great masters of the art of Government, the Romans-have succeeded in founding and in holding a great Empire in the teeth of infinitely more vigorous opposition than the Arabs ever had to face. By the end of the third century after the Hegira, the Arab element in the Caliphate had been forced to abdicate in favour of the Persians and the Turks and a Turkish general could say in Bagdad "What use are Arabs, now without the prophet and angelic aid." Two centuries more passed and the Arab, as a ruler, only maintained himself in Arabia, in Spain, and, competing with the indigenous Berber in the king. doms of Barbary. True, the Turk always lacked the attractive, if superficial, brilliancy of his rival. He was not an orator, nor did he ever show himself more than a copyist in literature. But he possessed a full share of those solid qualities which make for political success, and a firmness of will and character which atoned for his inferiority as compared with the Arab in acuteness and quickness of intelligence. The Arab could theorise ad libitum on Government, but he never seems to have taken the trouble to put the excellent theories which he had evolved or learnt from Greeks and Persians into practise. The Ottoman Empire of to-day is not in the best odour among progressive Europeans but let them compare it with the 'Empire' of Morocco! In Turkey there are signs that some at least of the Turks realise that progress is desirable, that scientific education is not altogether baneful, that railways and telegraphs are useful and that military affairs are better conducted when some sort of organisation (however indifferently worked) replaced administrative chaos. True, the Turkish War Office is a failure when it is involved in a tropical campaign, the railways are almost entirely under the management of Europeans, and the progressive in frowned upon by Yildiz Kiosk. But bad as is the system, it is civilisation-first quality hors concours - compared with the tribal anarchy of Morocco or Nejd and the barbaric tyranny of the 'black Arabs' who depopulated the Sudan. We do not wish to maintain that the Turkish Empire is a monument of good administration: If it were so it would not be exposed to the constant menace of dismemberment which harasses the lives ot its statesmen, but we submit that with all its faults the Turkish Empire--notably in its Asiatic provinces shows a great advance on any Arob achievement. It is an amazing feat for a race numbering some 7,000,000 souls to have held together a large Empire peopled by many diverse races, serving a multitude of creeds for over 500 years, in the teeth of the opposition not only of great European states but of large sections of their own subjects. The Arabs, the Kurds, the Druses, the Greek and Slay races of the Balkan, the Armenians, have all at one time or another rebelled against the Empire, but in every case except when supported by European nations, have succumbed to the sword or to the statecraft of their riders. The most ardent Turcophobe cannot minimise the importance of these achievements, the most ardent Arabophile cannot produce such evidence of political capacity on behalf of the race which he champions.

We do not in this article make any reference to the 'Arabs' i.e. Arab speaking peoples of Syria, and Egypt. To describe the Egyptian Moslems as Arabs is grossly inaccurate, as inaccurate as would be the assertion that the English were of Norman origin. The Egyptian Moslems must be in most cases converted Copts, crossed with Arab, Turk, Circassian and Sudanese blood. In Syria, though in the trans-Jordan districts, certain areas are inhabited by a fairly pure Arab population, the great mass of the Moslem population must be Syrian, descended from the converted 'mawalis' (clients) who embraced Islam after the conquest. In neither of these countries is there any evidence of any great racial change having followed the Arab invasions. The invaders were not like the Northern Barbarians or the Mongols-a whole people on the mareh--they came in small armies and though many settled in the conquered countries they can never have formed, more than a small section of the population, though strangely enough they seem to have been more numerously settled in Morocco and Algeria.

div.head: Hungarian Celebration.
div.p: At ten o'clock on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of the Coronation of Emperor François Joseph, Apostolic King of Hungary, Mass will be celebrated at the Coptic Church, at which the Austro-Hungarian Consul and staff will assist. A reception will afterwards be held at the Consulate.

div.head: French Minor Rescued.
div.p: The police visited a house of ill-repute in the Ezbekieh district on Tuesday evening last and discovered a little French girl, whom they have transferred to a benevolent home. The woman in whose house the child was found has been brought before the French Consul to answer a serious charge, as the girl is a minor.

div.head: Cairo Carriage Accident.
div.p: Mr. E. Campbell, of Glasgow, with his wife, while driving down the steep incline leading from the Citadel, and accompanied by a dragoman, met with a serious accident. The carriage was proceeding at a rapid pace when one of the wheels encountered an obstacle and all the occupants of the vehicle were violently thrown out, sustaining injuries, which necessitated their immediate removal to the Citadel Hospital. The dragoman and driver also received several nasty cuts. A native unable to avoid the carriage as it upset was instantly killed.

div.p: Le chiffre des affaires, loin d'augmenter, est plutôt en diminution. Il est actuellement si réduit qu'on parle d'ouvrir la séance à 10 h. ? et de la clôturer à 11 h. . Pour notre part nous ne saurions qu'approuver une telle mesure, si elle était prise par le comité, car la longueur des séances, en l'absence des affaires, ne peut que nuire au soutien du marché.

div.head:
THE HOME GOVERNMENT.
POLICY IN EGYPT.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)

London, Thursday, Sir Walter Mieville writing to the "Evening News" points out that should there be any weakening on the part of the Government in the support of Lord Cromer's policy in Egypt it will end in their innings being cut short by a storm of popular indignation.

div.head:
PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA
ARREST OF UNDESIRABLES.
div.p: A step in the right direction for the clearing of the streets of Alexandria of women of ill repute was taken by the police last night, when several of the women who make Boulevard de Ramleh so objectionable after dark were arrested, and are detained by the police pending instructions from their various Consuls, We are afraid that the sort of vice practised by these women is a prevalent evil but that it is impossible to keep the women out of the streets altogether, but the state of the Boulevard de Ramleh had certainly become disgraceful; indeed some of our readers have complained that it has of late been almost impossible to walk along it at night without being accosted, and even at times molested.

div.head: THE LATE LT. BRADFORD.
div.p: The awfully sudden death of the late Lieutenant Bradford of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, writes our military correspondent, which took place whilst attending an examination at Cork has drawn considerable attention to the manner in which officers are continually harrassed by these examinations, which, in many cases, seem to serve no good purpose, or at least any purpose equivalent to the mental anxiety and study they demand. In no other profession is the aspirant so rigorusly examined as in the army. From the day he enters Sandhurst, a light hearted cadet, until he leaves the service, in which he has grown grey and crabbed, the officer is examined for this, that, and the other, until his soul sickens at the very word. The rigorous examinations at Sandhurst and "The Shop" qualify him for the privelege of receiving a labourer's wage, and for being shot on a moment's notice, or done to death in some vile climate, to where our criminals were formerly deported. When he advances on the road to promotion in his regiment, he finds himself stopped by further examinations, and though he have the best may word' of command in his battalion, and may excel in drill, horsemanship and every soldierly duty, and have risked his life and limb in action, and behaved gallantly, he may find" himself shelved by failing to take the necessary 1 percentage of marks in the absurd questions with which the examinations bristle. It does not matter that he led his men very straight against the enemy, he does not know the particulars of some forgotten campaign, or cannot answer some idiotic point of military law, in which common sense could be the only guide in practical work. He leaves the army disgusted and disappointed to give room to paper soldiers. Annually, the army loses some of its best men through these ever recurring exams.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive attended midday prayers at Terbana mosque accompanied by the Governor, and afterwards returned to Ras-el-Tin Palace. His Highness has presented Saba Pasha with a signed photograph of himself.

div.head:
THE REMAINS OF GEORGE
AVEROFF.
div.p: The Hellenie community of Alexandria in harmony with the strong national feeling expressed in the centre of Hellenism, is preparing itself for a grand manifestation of patriotism on the occasion of the removal of the remains of the great patriot George Averoff, from Alexandria to Athens. The Greek nation has always been distinguished for the great number of its patriots, men heartily devoted to the national cause, and always ready to make any sacrifice for the attainment of the national aspirations.

Amongst these men a prominent place is held by George Averoff. He was, in the literal sense of the word, a true and pure patriot. What he did for his country, he did it in a pure patriotic spirit. He avoided all ostentation. He never searched for honours, which he deliberately avoided. In spite of repeated and warm invitations he avoided visiting Athens the principal centre of his beneficent action and where he knew that his incessant and well conceived liberalities would have secured him a triumphal reception, such as by right belonged to him. But he was always against all show and pomp, thinking that all he was doing was simply his duty.

George Averoff lavished his treasures in -endowing Alexandria, as well as the capital of Greece with splendid educational and philanthropic establishments. But rare has been his good fortune in connecting his name and his memory with his inspired gift to Athens of the glorious Stadism, which does more in raising the spirit and breathing patriotic enthusiasm into the souls of young Greeks than could do many universities together.

In fact Greece, by the munificence of her sons, has been able to acquire educational philanthropic establishments, such as much bigger countries do not possess and which the Government would never have been able to supply with its own resources.

Imperative national requirements have always strained these resources and have necessitated the expenditure of public money, which would, otherwise, have been devoted to such necessary establishments.

But these expenditures were unavoidable. When the Cretans, unable to bear the miseries of a Turkish administration, had repeatedly to revolt against the established order of things, and Cretan women and children had to take refuge, in the mother country, the Greek government and the Greek people had to give to the sympathetic helpless all requisite assistance, no matter at what sacrifice. And in quite recent times the Bulgarian atrocities entailed upon Greece as a State, and upon the Greeks as individuals. the same moral obligations and pecuniary sacrifices.

Not only the people individually had to contribute considerably towards the maintenance of the refugees, but also the Government had, out of its exhausted treasury, to supply the means of subsistence to the thousands of helpless people who had the right to appeal to them for help.
Thus the Greek exchequer was invariably left in a needy condition and, consequently, unable to attend to so many requirements, demanding attention in a civilized state.

Schools, universities, academies, observatories, and gymnasiums were very necessary institutions, but would certainly have been left on one side, in presence of the more urgent demand for bread by women and children the women and children of men who were sacrificing their lives for the liberty of their fellow countrymen and the grandeur of their mother country.

But the Greeks are very active and successful men of business, enriching themselves in whatever part of the globe they establish themselves, and above all they are good patriots. What, then, the Government would not have afforded to do, or would have been tardy in doing, has been done, in a magnificent way too, by the munificence of patriotic Greek citizens.

Educational establishments of all sorts and grades, hospitals kept in the best style and endowed with the latest scientific contrivances, and all the resources of comfort have been founded in Athens, and entertained by the donations of generous Greeks, working hard and intelligently in all parts of the world.

Of all the innumerable atid great benefactors of Greece, none enlists so much the sympathy and admiration of his fellow-countrymen, as this simple and unassuming man, who did his duty towards his country with the greatest modesty.
It is not then surprising that Greece should desire to have and conserve in her own soil the remains of such a good man and such a pure patriot as George Averoff.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: FOURTH SUMMER MEETING.
FIRST DAY'S RACING.

Yesterday afternoon the first day of the Fourth summer meeting of the Alexandria Sporting Club was held under ideal weather conditions. The attendance, though very poor, showed a slight improvement over previous meetings. The running was good, though there were no sensational wins, or even places, but the betting was lively and well distributed, so that the afternoon was most enjoyable. We must again congratulate the Committee upon the smartness with which the results of the Pari Mutuel were published, though at the same time the payment on winning tickets and the selling of tickets might be expedited slightly. The crowd to be dealt with is not great and there is room for some improvement in this direction. Considerable interest was centred on the last race, there being only three runners, Aida, Princess, and Gouvernant, and therefore no place betting. The betting was fairly even on Gouvernant and Princess, the former being slightly the favourite, while Aida found not a few to take a sporting chance on her success. The race in itself was also fairly exciting, for it was not until the bend had been passed that Gouvernant could be looked upon as a certain winner. Indeed for a good part of the course the race appeared to be in favour of Princess. The fifth race received, a somewhat undue interest, owing to the name of the two horses of The Angel's having been changed from Veronique to The Undesirable and Ulema to Paterfamilias. The usual superstition that when a horse's name is changed its luck will turn was evident, and both were fairly well backed. Our readers will, of course, presume that the change in name, in both eases, was intended as an answer to the letter of "Paterfamilias" appearing in the columns of the "Egyptian Gazette" a few days ago. "Paterfamilias" however, will be glad to learn that The Undesirable did not gain even a place, whereas the horse which has assumed his nom de plume came in second. It is always a matter of regret to see a good horse beaten, and this was generally felt when Carlton broke its succession of wins, by being beaten by Aurelius, but then 2 stone 7 is a lot of weight to concede. Backers however did not desert Carlton, the betting being fairly divided between the two, and it will be interesting to see how they acquit themselves at their next meeting on Saturday.

The five starters came away well together, Kara Aslan making the pace from Rainbow, with Nadim close behind. The order was unchanged until the bend had been passed when Rainbow took the lead, but Nadim coming away at a big pace secured first place with ease by about a couple of lengths.
Totalisator paid P.T. 51. 1st P.T. 24, 2nd P.T. 20, 3rd P.T. 41.

0 From a good start led by Pan, with Kordofan and Radium doing apparently rather badly, the race was fairly evenly run up to the bend. Telmese, then drew ahead, but Radium was coming up at a rattling pace, with Fadaan and Shendi close behind. The excitement was great, and until close up to the post it was impossible to pronounce any of the four as a winner. Fadaan, however, just got home from Radium, by a short head with Shendi a good third.

After some delay at the post owing to the fractiousness of two or three horses a fairly good start was made with Sihami slightly to the lead, but was overtaken on the bend by Vandal, followed by Sadik. Sadik and Vandal however again gave way to Siham and Atbara the latter coming at a big pace, but could only finish a good third to Siham and Sadik.

At the very start Roland came away and took a long lead, being lengths ahead round the bend. Passing the post the order was Roland, Padgham, London, Tokar, Shour, Valentino, Abou Nadara, El Tahawi, and Rachid, the last two being well tailed off. Roland kept his lead till coming round the bend the second time when Abou Nadara came away and led the field from Roland and Valentino these three finishing as placed.

Handicap for horses classes II and I of New Racing Rules. Distance 1 mile. H.E. Khalil Pasha Khayat's ch.e.h. Aurelius,
8.0. Digby. The Angels' b.e.h. Paterfamilias (late Ulema),
6.7. Galley Saleh Bey Yaghen's c.e.h. Carlton, 10.7.

Watchman, 5.7. Ibrahim.

Carlton led at the start with Aurelius close behind, Bonus coming next with Paterfamilias, but coming round the bend Aurelius got ahead and looked certain for a win, bar accident. Carlton dropped astonishingly and Aurelius had no difficulty in keeping first place, coming in a winner by a short length. Paterfamilias was a good second, and Carlton made a very poor third. It is notable that this is the first time the latter has met with defeat in this country, but seeing the weight it was conceding it acquitted itself as well as could be expeeted.
Totalisator paid :-P.T. 44. 1st P.T. 20, 2nd P.T. 46, 3rd P.T. 21.

Although only a small field went to the post, a good start was made Princess taking a slight lead from Gouvernant. When half the distance was covered Gouvernant overtook Prinoess but they were almost neck and neck until coming into the straight, when Gouvernant romping away from Princess won easily by ten lengths.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, to spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EaYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir.- Was "Paterfamilias" or an "Irate Husband" at the races to day ! Did they see anything of the scandal referred to by them in their letters, or "Excluded" witness a "parade of undesirables."? I went, and having read the correspondence in your columns was on the "quis vive," but the only "undesirable" I saw, or could find any objection to was on the race card, and this was very much an undesirable to those who booked it. May I also remark on the fact that although I have watched for a reply from "Paterfamilias" defending his objection against the letters of your correspondents, none has been forthcoming, and it appears that "Pater familias" for the want of something better to do endeavours to open up a controversy and then like brer rabbit "Lies low and says nothing."
Yours truly,
TO THE EDITOR OF TARZAYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir. -- "Paterfamilias" and "Irate Husband" should blush when discovering that they are "Peeping Toms" gifted with too keen eyesight, mis-directed during the intervals between races. Does "Sportsman's" observation sadly need sharpening when he detects a "glaring evil" "in the dusk." 1. Impartials" logie is at fault. It undesirables find access to theatres, halls and other public places, is that any reason for admitting them to a members enclosure of a private race course. "Diogenes" with wide Eastern experience has never seen a better behaved Eastern town than Alexandria at night, and he thinks other race courses are worse than ours. The issue is a very plain one. Do the members approve of the present state of affairs and wish it continued | Let them say yes or no. If no, is there any objection to admitting members to a member's enclosure, and their friends, on presentation of their visiting card with the friend's name written on it ? All clubs hold the introducer responsible for the person introduced. The race course used to be a social gathering as much as a sporting one, and on non-masing days the grounds are considered private. The "undesirables" must be wanting time and money in going to a place where their presence has been so unnoticed except by "Paterfamilias" and "Irate Husband " Their absence then would be no loss to themselves or others, and the sooner it is brought about the better.
Yours truly
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN Gazette."

Sir, --I have been following with interest the correspondence in your paper respecting the company at the races, and consider that a solution could be easily arrived at by following the example of our best clubs in England and instituting a member's enclosure. The Sporting Club suffers from two unavoidable difficulties up to the present moment. (1) The space is extremely small and one is necessarily brought into closest contact with all comers and (2) there is the usual international multitude, which views things from different points of view. But as far as I can make out all the right minded people of every race would not consider the establishment of a members enclosure in the light of a 'clique, but as a right due to a private club As the race course is soon to be moved it would be very easy to arrange to make two separate enclosures, the one for members, to include the grand stand as well as their own refreshment tables whilst the public would have their enclosure with stand and tes tables etc.

This arrangement would certainly increase the prestige of the club and there would at once be an increase of members. They would also feel themselves obliged to be more circumspect in their invitations to their own enclosure and the compliment would certainly be far greater to their guests. After all we should be only copying Ascot, Henley, Ranelagh, and Hurlingham.
Yours, etc.,

div.head: CAESAR'S CAMP.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir.-In answer to "Carmencita's" letter of yesterday, I may state that I was perbape & little over zealous, but I don't think I committed blunders. If I remember rightly, Sarah Bernhardt was not carried off the rails, but actually confronted the modern ap to-date means of conveyance, stood her ground, and showed herself a woman in the true sense of the word. She could not afford to lose her time by indulging in trivial polemios. As regards you, sweet "Dulcamara," your wit is deserving of more consideration. I should really like to know who you are ; whether you are a Venus in disguise, as your sweet name would insinuate or, whether you are a "glaring" or "green-eyed monster." I don't I know how the "sleeping beauty" fared (in fact I hadn't the time to inquire, as I had many calls, even in my leisure time but I think, that he deserved, if nothing else, a sound hiding. But Perhaps he will get his deserts in due time.
We all, sweet "Dulcamara," like to preserve our lives. Wouldn't you, as much as another, | like to preserve yours !?? Perhaps you would do so without trying to benefit humanity. Yours truly,

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Jeudi 6 Juin 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 3 5/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté hier avarié à 84, de même que l'Unifiée à 100 1/4. La National Bank a rétrogradé de non moins de 1/2 livré à 22 1/2. La Daïra a perdu 1/8 à 15. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 8 1/2, ainsi que la Delta Light à 9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien a réactionné de 1 franc à 711 et la Banque d'Athènes d'autant à. 127.

Ici, la physionomie générale du marché a été moins morose qu'hier ; mais la tendance à la lourdeur n'en a pas moins persisté malgré un calme plat et des transactions clairsemées. En réalité, les offres ont été encore nombreuses, mais elles ne tombaient pas constamment dans le vide, signe que la situation pourrait bien être à la veille de s'améliorer.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National an encore fléchi de 1/8 à 22 7/16. L'Agricole s'est alourdie à 8 5/16. La Cassa di Sconto a été ramenée à 158..
Le Crédit Foncier a été délaissé à 710. L'Enterprise and Development a faibli à 10.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont reculé à 203.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été mieux tenus à 18 3/4.
Rien de saillant à relever dans le compartiment des petites valeurs.
Suivant des informations reçues par le courrier d'hier, des syndicats seraient en voie de formation à Londres, à Paris et à Bruxelles pour l'achat de valeurs égyptiennes.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 31 Mai, le passage suivant :

"Notre marché a continué à être inactif et faible durant presque toute la semaine. Monte Fois aujourd'hui, grâce à une amélioration signalée d'Egypte et à quelques ordres d'achat reçus de là-bas, la tendance est devenue meilleure. C'est ainsi que la National Bank, qui cotait 22 7/8 vendredi dernier et qui était offerte hier à 22 5/8, a été négociée ce soir jusqu'à 23 1/4 pour finir à 23 1/8. L'Agricole a également éprouvé l'effet de ses meilleures
dispositions et a terminé à -8 3/8 après avoir , atteint 8 7/16. Parmi les petites valeurs, les
Markets ont été aussi demandés, et de 24 sh. ils ont passé à 26. Les Estates sont en reprise à 1 3/8 après 1 9/32 et les New Egyptian à 0 15/16 après 17 sh.
L'argent pour les reports à la liquidation fin Mai a été d'environ 1/2 pour cent plus cher qu'à la liquidation précédente."

L'assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Société Anonyme des Eaux du Caire a été tenue hier, dans l'après-midi, sous la présidence de S.E. Boghos pacha Nubar, pour délibérer sur la proposition du conseil d'administration relative à la création d'actions de jouissance nouvelles.
Le nombre d'actions représentées était de plus de 290,000, soit les deux tiers environ de la totalité.
Le président a longuement exposé dans un rapport les raisons qui ont déterminé le conseil à recourir à ce moyen ; on trouvera cette note explicative dans les journaux...

D'autre part, le président a annoncé que la Société vient de conclure avec l'Etat une convention pour la vente des terrains attenant aux filtres de l'Abbassieh. Par cette convention, le gouvernement consent à la Société le quart de tous les bénéfices que la vente de ces terrains pourra permettre à la Compagnie de réaliser. La part revenant à la Société équivaut à 68,000 mètres carrés.

A l'unanimité des voix, l'assemblée a voté la proposition du conseil, et sur la proposition de S.E Chakour pacha, elle a, en outre, exprimé sa confiance dans le conseil " qui a consciencieusement et brillamment géré les affaires de la Société depuis de si longues années."
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Cairo Exchange Ltd. sont informés que les certificats provisoires des actions ordinaires et des parts de fondateurs sont délivrés aux bureaux de MM. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, rue Kasr-el-Nil, au Caire, contre les lettres de répartition et les reçus des versements effectués à la souscription et à la répartition."

Les recettes de l'Alexandria Ramleh Railway Co. pour la semaine au ler Juin courant se sont élevées à L. E. 1,466 contre 1,281 en 1906, soit en augmentation de L.E. 185. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Octobre 1906 se chiffrent par L.E. 43,897 contre 37,069 pour l'exercice précédent, soit en plus-value de L.E. 6,825.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier
div.p: "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l'"Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samedi midi, de façon pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales de coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les dernières statistique aes jusqu'à la veille de sa publication : des tables ax des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles on yoyons la Liverpool Cotton Association, eto. etc.
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte ootte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour L'Étranger 10 P.T. de port ea eas

div.head: SAILING VESSEL BLOWN UP. CAPTAIN REFUSES SURRENDER.

div.p: A large sailing vessel with a contraband cargo of rifles and powder was surrounded in the darkness by armed French customs' boats near the Tripolitan frontier. The captain refused to surrender and blew up his vessel. It is believed that 70 persons have been killed as there were a number of native boats alongside unloading,
(Reuter)
The number of deaths from the explosion of the sailing vessel at Zarzis is 35.
(Havas)
The "inscrits maritimes" are working at Bordeaux, Nantes, Cherbourg, and Toulon. There is great activity at Marseilles.
(Havas)
The Chamber has commenced the discussion on the wine-growing crisis. It will resume tomorrow morning.
(Havas)

The dissolution of the Municipality has been decreed. It will be replaced by a commission under the presidency of a Peer of the Realm. This is connected with the political crisis which in some quarters is described as dynastie.
(Reuter)
A Bulgarian emphatic note demands the speedy withdrawal of Servian bands from Macedonia.
(Reuter)
A squadron of Hussars of the Guard at Tsarskoe Selo has mutinied. The ringleaders have been arrested.
(Reuter)
The Duma has voted the discussion of amnesty for Saturday. This resolution is greatly commented upon on account of the consequences it might have.
(Havas)
The Emperor has arrived for the jubilee fêtes of drowning. Unequalled ovations were given.
(Havas)

div.head: LAUNCHING OF HELIOPOLIS.
div.p: DEVELOPMENT OF EGYPT.

We have now received fuller details of the launching of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company's steamer the Heliopolis on Tuesday week. Among those present on the launching platform were the Earl and Countess of Dalkeith, Lord Armstrong, chairman of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, with Lady Armstrong, Mr. Alfred Curphy, Mr. G.T. Symons, (with Mrs Symons) and Major C.H. Villiers, directors of the company; - Mr. A. Gracie, Colonel Paget Mosley, Mr. A. W. Sampson, Mr. A. Cleghorn, and Mr. G. Strachan, of the Fairfield Company; Captain Crighton, marine superintendent of the owning company, and Mr. M.G. Isdale, superintendent engineer; Mr. Arthur Piers and Captain Mowatt, Canadian Pacific Railway; Mr Samuel Roberts, M.P.; Rear Admiral Bearcroft, Professor George Adam Smith, Lieutenant-Colonel Ferguson Buchanan, Mr. W.M. Rhodes, Mr. J. P. Spanier, Mr. A.K. McCosh, of Cairnhall, Mr. J.R. Cuthbertson, and Mr. Lewis Evans.

The huge vessel moved slowly down the ways, the launch occupying about 55 sees, and so easily did she take the water that the checking chains were never taut. When the boat was safely waterborne, a rousing cheer was raised by the spectators.

After the launch the invited guests repaired to the Board-room, where luncheon was served. Mr. Alex. Gracie presided, and proposed the loyal toasts, which were duly acknowledged. Colonel Paget Mosley gave the toast of "The Countess of Dalkeith.." He apologised for the absence of Sir William Pearse, the chairman of the Company, and on behalf of the directors presented the Countess with a casket containing the ivory hatchet with which her Ladyship had cut the launching cord. The Earl of Dalkeith responded, and wished success to ship and owners.

The Chairman submitted the toast of "Success to the Heliopolis." It was a bold stroke, he said, for a new company to bid for the Egyptian traffic, which had for so long a period been in the hands of old-established steamship companies ; but the interest, he might almost say fascination, attaching to Egypt, not only from its antiquity, but also from its modern history and development, had already created a traffic which was yearly increasing, and they were all indebted to the enterprise of the directors of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, who had had the courage to undertake this new service, which would put us within such easy travelling distance of a country so closely associated with our own, through such men as Gordon, Baker, Kitchener, and last, but by no means least, that great statesman, Lord Cromer, who had jest returned after an almost unprecedented record of honourable service. (Applause.) The whole-hearted manner in which the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company had tackled this business by building such magnificent vessels as the Heliopolis and the Cairo augured well for their future success, which, he ventured to prediet, would be all they desired, as it would certainly be no less than they deserved. (Applause.)

Lord Armstrong, in responding, said nine months had elapsed since the contract was signed for the. Heliopolis and the Cairo, the first two boats of this new line, and they were then told by the Fairfield Company that the first of these vessels would be ready for launching in May. Well, they had fulfilled their promise to the letter, in spite of the serious strike which took place last autumn, and he ventured to say that they had thereby enhanced their great reputation, and shown what energy, organisation, and skilled workmanship could do in surmounting what to some would be insuperable obstacles. He had no doubt the Heliopolis and the Cairo would be completed before the end of the year, and that they would be carrying passengers to Egypt during the coming winter season. He should like to take this opportunity of saying a few words as to their object in building those two vessels which would be the largest, the fastest, and the most luxuriously equipped passenger boats in the Mediterranean, equal in nearly every respect to the great Atlantic liners: Under the protection of Great Britain and under the direction of the great ProConsul who had just retired, seconded as he had been by a most able band of lieutenants, Egypt had emerged from a state of chaos and bankruptcy to one of great prosperity. (Applause.) Formerly visited only by a few wealthy people, it had now become, and it would even more and more in the future become, the great winter resort of those who could leave England for the winter season. According to Lord Cromer's reports, the number of visitors had doubled in the last five years-from sixty thousand to one hundred and twenty thousand and there' was no reason why the influx of visitors should not go on increasing in the future Then again, owing to its prosperity, Egypt had become the home of a considerable number of Europeans engaged in commerce and in developing the marvellous, resources of the country; and, thirdly, owing to our occupation of Egypt had become the residence of a large number of English officials. To meet the requirements of these three classes, to remedy the deficiencies of the present service, to cope with the constantly increasing traffic, and to improve the facilities for reaching the land of the Pharaohs, they had founded this line, and they hoped thereby to increase the comfort of the journey while shortening it by one and a half days, and to carry on under the British flag a service that would be recognised as second to none either in the Mediterranean or elsewhere. He thought they would agree with him that, relying as they did on the support and encouragement of the makers of Modern Egypt and on the inventive genius of Mr. Parsons, the inventor of the steam turbine and on the great constructive skill and reputation of the Fairfield Company, that was not an empty dream, but would soon be proved to be an accomplished fact. (Applause.) Some people said that we were descended from the old Vikings, and he trusted that those who manned their ships would always worthily uphold the traditions of our race. Again, others, with perhaps less authority, had said that we were descendants of the ancient Israelites, of whom they read that Egypt was glad of their departure. (Laughter.) However that might be, he trusted that they might turn the tables by making the modern Egyptians glad of their coming, and that they might be the means of adding to the further prosperity of that great country. (Applause.) His Lordship concluded by proposing "The Fairfield Company."
Mr. A.W. Sampson replied, and the toast of the chairman having been proposed by the Earl of Dalkeith, the proceedings terminated.

div.head: K. S. C.
div.p: POLO.
A match between the Mounted Infantry and the Kings Own Scottish Borderers was played at Ghezireh on Tuesday 4th, which proved fast and interesting.

The K. O. S. B. who are improving in their polo every day played a good game. But Mr. Jenkinson for the M. I. was 'indefatigable and by brilliant play won the match for his side. The teams were as follows: M. INFANTRY.
K. O.S. B. Mr. Cooper I.
Mr. Coulson I. Mr. Crake II.
Mr. Pennyman II. Mr. Wylie III. Mr. Furber III. Mr. Jenkinson (back). Capt. Stoney (back).

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.

There is no change in the weather conditions. The early mornings are cool and fresh, but the heat and humidity are increasing daily. This morning there is a light northerly breeze with a rising barometer.

div.head: EXTREME WEAKNESS CURED.
div.p: VITALISING QUALITIES OF DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.

It is very difficult to conceive a greater state of weakness than that felt by some women after childbirth. Their life hangs on a thread, and they are no more than a breath. It is necessary to administer a medicine of incomparable strength in order to bring about a normal state of health. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People are well known to wise women who, in the condition under notice, have always found them beneficial to an extraordinary degree. Mme. Madame A. Lippers (photo, Jacobs et Cie). It seemed to me that I had not a drop of blood in my veins, and I was so weak that I could scarcely move. Several treatments having failed to vitalise me, I was advised to take Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. I am indebted to you for what Dr. Williams' Pink Pills have done for me. One can easily understand that if Dr. Williams Pink Pills can cure cases of grave exhaustion, and anæmia, the chlorosis of young girls cannot resist the treatment of these pills. div.head: Credit Franco-Egyptien.
div.p: SOCIÉTÉ ANONYME AU CAPITAL DE 12.500.000 FRANCS
Assemblee Generale Annuelle.
MM. les Actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire pour le Vendredi 14 Juin 1907 à trois heures et demie de relevée, à la salle des Ingénieurs Civils, 19 Rue Blanche à Paris,
ORDRE DU JOUR. Examen et approbation des comptes de l'exercice clos le 31 Mars 1907.
Fixation du Dividende.
Nomination des Commissaires pour l'exercice 1907-1908.
Autorisations diverses.

Pour faire partie de l'Assemblée, il faut être propriétaire d'au moins 20 actions, les porteurs d'un nombre inférieur pourront toutefois se réunir pour atteindre ce chiffre et se faire représenter par l'un d'eux.
Pour assister à l'Assemblée, MM. les Actionnaires devront déposer leurs actions :
A Paris : au plus tard le 11 Juin 1907. lo.-Au Siège Social, 3 Rue Saint-Georges.
20.--Au Crédit Mobilier Français, 3 & 5 Rue Saint-Georges et aux Caisses de tous les Établissements de Crédit de Paris et de leurs succursales.
En Egypte : au plus tard le 31 Mai 1907. 1o.-Au Siège de la Direction à Alexandrie.
20.-Aux caisses du Crédit Lyonnais, du Comptoir National d'Escompte, de l'Anglo Egyptian Bank, de la Banque Impériale Ottomane et de la Deutsche Orient Bank.

Les récépissés de dépôt effectués en d'autres lieux qu'au Siège Social à Paris et au siège de la Direction à Alexandrie devront parvenir au Siège social ou au siège de la Direction dans les délais respectifs plus haut indiqués du 11 Juin 1907 et du 31 Mai 1907 : ces récépissés devront mentionner les numéros des actions déposées.
Les pouvoirs des Actionnaires qui useront de la faculté de groupement devront être remis dans les mêmes délais.
